# Changes with observed prices and quantities

I estimate the price and quantities with the additional costs to the observed data. These are compared with the model estimates and the observed data. I compute the percentage changes in the price and quantity for fed cattle, cull cows as well as the aggregate producer surplus. The results are as follows:

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in price of fed cattle}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_ps\_obs & percentChange\_ps\_model \\ \hline
2010  &        -6.5766982     &          1.6306733\\
2011  &       -14.1895916     &          1.4796200\\
2012  &       -2.5595639      &          1.2555068\\
2013  &          0.7641544    &          1.1590637\\
2014  &        -16.0369276    &          1.1186796\\
2015  &          7.0056582    &          0.8945503\\
2016  &         26.6988327    &          0.9035895 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}


\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in quantity of fed cattle}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_sl\_obs & percentChange\_sl\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &         0.5114821   &        -1.617407e-14 \\
 2011   &         0.3457242   &          0.000000e+00 \\
 2012   &        -2.7404237   &         0.000000e+00 \\
 2013   &         0.2974021   &         -1.643580e-14 \\
 2014   &        -2.5022686   &       -1.675859e-14 \\
 2015   &        -0.7994106   &       -1.773940e-14 \\
 2016   &         1.2584954   &        1.734328e-14 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

Here we have percentage change from the observed data and model respectively. The fed cattle price fell compared to observed, this is reflected in the quantities. The quantities went up by a little. The fed cattle prices went up compared to the model estimates. However, the quantities changed very little. Note that the price went by a little so we expect the same change in the quantities. 


\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in price of cull cows}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_pc\_obs & percentChange\_pc\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &         -22.305687    &             3.535708 \\
 2011   &         -22.916642    &            2.729425 \\
 2012   &         -11.560880    &            2.094137 \\
 2013   &          -1.322547    &            1.829043 \\
 2014   &         -23.717126    &            1.767165 \\
 2015   &           1.929532    &            1.353151 \\
 2016   &          37.000319    &            1.363775 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in quantity of cull cows}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_cl\_obs & percentChange\_cl\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &        -0.5767056     &     1.130325e-05 \\
 2011   &         9.1561672     &      8.016228e-06 \\
 2012   &         8.1515734     &      1.013729e-05 \\
 2013   &        -8.3312239     &      1.063030e-05 \\
 2014   &        14.6568011     &     -1.535018e-05 \\
 2015   &        12.9117106     &      1.151384e-05 \\
 2016   &        11.5011345     &      9.786865e-06 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

Although prices fell for cull cows (compared to observed prices), the quantities remained almost same. However the prices went up when compared to the model estimates and the quantities remained same or fell by a little. 


Just note that cattle cycles play important role too. The observed data (especially stocks), follows the expansion and contraction of the stocks so our model does the same.


\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Aggregate producer surplus}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & diffRevCost\_t\_obs & diffRevCost\_t\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &     -2.1681188    &      -0.1577323 \\
 2011   &     -4.4930972    &      -0.1707075 \\
 2012   &     -2.1005092    &      -0.1675756 \\
 2013   &     -0.4705478    &      -0.1437623 \\
 2014   &     -6.9141243    &      -0.1545304 \\
 2015   &      1.8134526    &      -0.1474051 \\
 2016   &      7.5518716    &      -0.1561541 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

The aggregate producer surplus is negative for the first 5 years and then positive when we compare it to the observed data. However it is negative all the way when compared to the model.


# Changes with observed prices and quantities until 2009 and then model estimates from 2010

I estimate the price and quantities with the additional costs to the model estimates. These are compared with the model estimates and the observed data. I compute the percentage changes in the price and quantity for fed cattle, cull cows as well as the aggregate producer surplus. The results are as follows:

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in price of fed cattle}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_ps\_obs & percentChange\_ps\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &        -10.603034    &        -2.74938210 \\
 2011   &        -15.509197    &         -0.08094854 \\
 2012   &         -3.289823    &          0.49665633 \\
 2013   &         -1.321448    &         -0.93471286 \\
 2014   &        -16.989992    &         -0.02911836 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in quantity of fed cattle}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_sl\_obs & percentChange\_sl\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &         11.741485     &         11.172856 \\
 2011   &          4.600009     &          4.239627 \\
 2012   &         -0.277849     &          2.531961 \\
 2013   &          7.310272     &          6.992075 \\
 2014   &          1.570732     &          4.177534 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

The fed cattle price fell compared to observed, this is reflected in the quantities. The quantities went up. The fed cattle prices fell compared to the model estimates. Again, the quantities went up reflecting the fall in prices.

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in price of cull cows}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_pc\_obs & percentChange\_pc\_model \\ \hline
 2010   &         -14.62216       &      13.774801 \\
 2011   &         -20.53594       &        5.902204 \\
 2012   &         -10.45579       &        3.369853 \\
 2013   &           2.05221       &        5.311585 \\
 2014   &         -22.29011       &        3.670906 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Percentage change in quantity of cull cows}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & percentChange\_cl\_obs & percentChange\_cl\_model \\ \hline
 2010     &       10.454190      &        11.094893 \\
 2011     &       13.807654      &          4.261322 \\
 2012     &       11.214696      &          2.832260 \\
 2013     &       -1.974307      &          6.934670 \\
 2014     &       19.723108      &          4.418655 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

The cull cow prices fell compared to the observed. This is reflected in the quantities for the cull cows. However, the prices and quantities of cull cows went up compared to the model estimates. This is a strange phenomena.


\begin{table}[!ht]
\begin{center}
\caption{Aggregate producer surplus}
\begin{tabular}{lll}
\hline
Year & diffRevCost\_t\_obs & diffRevCost\_t\_model \\ \hline
 2010    &    -0.3326094       &     1.6777770 \\
 2011    &    -3.6351486       &    0.6872411 \\
 2012    &    -1.4358652       &    0.4970684 \\
 2013    &     1.4075129       &    1.7342984 \\
 2014    &    -5.7498617       &    1.0097323 \\\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{table}

The aggregate producer surplus fell when compared to the observed data. It went up when compared with the model estimates.
